reviews.review:
Echt ein tolles Rätsel-Spiel.
Man wacht in einer Zelle auf und wird von einer weiblichen Stimme begrüßt. Diese wird den Spieler auch in den weiterfolgenden Leveln Tipps und Tricks geben. Jedenfalls wird man sozusagen als Testperson benutzt und muss versuchen die Rätsel alle zu lösen und so die Tests zu bestehen.
Meiner Meinung nach konnten sie ruhig noch ein paar Level mehr dranhängen, immerhin sind Level 19 jetzt nicht die Welt und wenn man ziemlich gut in solchen Spielen ist, hat man es locker in zwei Stunden schon durch.
Ótimo jogo, só peca em ser meio curto, mas o preço vale a pena pela diversão !!
classic
Nice to have

Put simply, Portal is a great first-person platform game that uses FPS aesthetics as a tool in solving a given level.

You are a test subject for Aperture Science's greatest invention to date: the portal gun. Under the friendly guidance of GLaDOS, you progress through a series of testing rooms to determine your ability to surmount impossible obstacles using the portal gun. At the end, there will be cake.

It isn't a very long game -- maybe about five hours for the story mode; but the song that plays during the end credits is worth playing through the game multiple times, and some of the achievements will be pretty tough to unlock without [cheating] watching someone else do it on YouTube first. Aside from the story mode, there are challenges and bonus levels to extend your gameplay.

The short sell: if you don't have this game already, it's worth every penny.
Historia fácil, desafíos difíciles. Muy corto.
Delicious! Oh, wait...
this game is funny

Казалось бы, в основе геймплея лежит банальнейшая идея: есть портальная пушка, связывающая две точки комнаты, в которой ты находишься, двухсторонним порталом. Есть интерактивные объекты, способ взаимодействия с которыми очевиден. Задача элементарна - пройти дальше. Однако головоломки разнообразны и интересны, а использование порталов с непривычки знатно взрывает мозг. Стоит начать играть, и девиз игры - Think with portals - становится понятен.

По мере прохождения игрок будет ознакамливаться с вполне себе хорошим сюжетом и фирменным чёрным юмором; познакомится с главным антагонистом, которая настолько харизматична, что её будет жалко убивать; а в конце прослушает шикарнейшую финальную песню, в одну которую души вложено больше, чем во многие игры.

Если говорить о реализации, то тут не всё так красочно. Игра выпущена на движке второго халф-лайфа, причём от черт второго халф-лайфа не избавилась, что создаёт впечатление, что Portal - скорее мод, чем нечто самостоятельное (частично так оно и есть). Несмотря на то, что графика вполне радует глаз, дизайн выглядит непрофессионально и несколько несвязно. Местами появляется ощущение сырости и недоделанности. Завершает картину отвратная русская озвучка, с которой явно продешевили (советую играть с английской).

Вердикт: 8/10, но это одна из тех игр, с которой обязан познакомиться каждый. Хотя бы затем, чтобы после приступить к истинному шедевру - второй части игры.

[h1]A Paladin’s Steam Review: Portal. The Game and Whatever Cake You May Find, Isn’t A Lie[/h1]
[list]
[*]Genre: First Person Solo & Co-Op Puzzle Game
[*]Developed & Published by: Valve
[*]Platform Support: Windows, Mac, Linux, Android, Xbox 360 and PS3
[*]Business Model: Base Game.
[*][i]Copy purchased by myself[/i]
[/list]
[b]Preamble[/b]
Portal was included in the Orange Box, a package of titles that not only included the latest Half Life 2 episode but Valve’s new class based FPS title: Team Fortress 2. Portal was a new idea from Valve that they included in the box to see how much response it would get. I don’t think they counted on it being a cultural phenomenon. Portal was an unexpected surprise for gamers and a groundbreaking hit for Valve. Leading to memes, references and a whole new genre of gaming. For me to review this long afterwards the release is a little daunting. Will I say anything new or interesting? Well, I guess there’s only one way to find out. So, let’s take a look at the simply named: Portal. 
 
[b]Overall Gameplay Thoughts[/b]
Portal’s main mechanic is the portal gun, which shoots two portals creating doorways on portable surfaces. These allow the movement of objects to different places around the environment. Each environment is a series of rooms and chambers that you have to get past in order to progress forward. Usually, each room has an objective which ranges from putting a companion cube on a switch to delivering an energy orb to its collector. But there will be obstacles such as glass windows, unportable walls and more that will block your way. Your main objective is to figure out a way to use portals and the objects in the environment to get past the obstacles and move on to the next room. 

There’s around 19 individual levels that contain their own unique objective or set of objectives for you to get past. How you achieve this is up to you. After the initial set of levels, which are designed to introduce you to Portal’s main mechanics, the game opens up and becomes more free-form, allowing more than one solution to each room. In all, it’ll take about a couple of hours to complete the game. Which I consider to be the right amount of content for what the game has to offer. 

[b]Puzzle Difficulty and Mechanics[/b]
Portal is probably the easiest entry into the series but its still a challenge for new players. Each puzzle is designed to build upon the previously introduced mechanic in new and potentially strange ways. It works to Portal’s advantage to prevent the player from being overwhelmed. There’s companion cubes, switches, energy pellets, acidic water pits, portal flinging and more. All of which gives you obstacles and objectives to keep you busy. Unfortunately, Portal lacks replayability. There isn’t much of a reason to replay the main campaign outside of listening to developer commentary or achievements. There are extra challenge modes in the bonus section to extend the game a little farther if you need just a little bit more out of the title. 

Overall, I’d say Portal is easy enough to solve without needing to look up a guide but challenging enough to keep you guessing. It does a really good job of keeping each mechanic satisfying, subtly teaching you every step of the way on how to use the new mechanics. Much of the challenge I found with Portal (1) was with the portal flinging mechanic. Which is where you jump into portals and build your momentum up to reach new heights or portable areas. As it requires split-second decisions and mistakes are harshly punished (requiring you to reset the entire sequence over), it can be as frustrating as first person platforming. But it’s really my only complaint I have with it. 

[b]Story & Characters[/b]
The story is centered around the interactions of Chell, the protagonist you play as, and GLaDOS. The AI overlord whose only interest is “science” and Chell’s constant completion of the tests. She’ll make quips about your progress, comments about Aperture Science and a few humorous statements now and then. Which I like because we don’t get enough humor in games as-is. Well, not without it being over the top or forced. And don’t worry, no matter how good (or bad) you are at Portal. You’re still bad in GLaDOS’ eyes. But you get to live so long as you continue to work for the betterment of science. Chell has no choice but to continue the tests. All the while, looking for a way out of this [i]rat’s maze[/i]. I should mention that Chell is a silent protagonist but the writing is done well enough to keep the story moving. It’s not exactly the most expansive plot or story but it’s simple and sweet in its own way. If you’re looking for a more complex/thrilling plot, there’s the sequel for that. 

[b]PC Settings, Visuals and Audio[/b]
Portal’s setting menu is very similar to Half Life 2 in look and function. There’s portal assisted aiming and rendering options. Mouse settings include sensitivity adjustments and acceleration if desired. The Keyboard can be fully rebound though most of the controls are standard. Controllers are supported as well with the option to adjust sensitivity and swap sticks. Audio sliders, speaker configurations, captions and there’s multiple languages to choose from. 

Video options include, well, a lot of things. Model, Texture, Shader, Water and Shadow details can be set from low to high. There’s color correction too. Anti-aliasing mode has multiple settings including CSAA and MSAA from 2-16X. There’s also anisotropic up to 16X. V-sync is a simple enabled/disabled along with motion blur. Multi-core rendering is also featured as well as HDR and bloom. The field of view slider goes from 75 to 90 and while 90 is a bit on the skimpy side, it should be enough for most players. 

Visually, Portal 1 has a slightly grimier and dirtier look than it’s sequel but still maintains a clean aesthetic. What impresses me about Portal is how good it still holds up after all this time. Even compared to its sequel. I have little doubt that Portal will continue to age incredibly well as the years go by. The soundtrack is ok, it’s an electronic set of tracks with a more atmospheric and computer-like feel to it. It’s not exactly the most memorable but it does work. 

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
Portal is about thinking puzzles through, slowly and methodically while having moments of high-speed thrills. I prefer to think of Portal 1 as the shorter but sweeter predecessor to Portal 2. The game length is near perfect. Every puzzle has their place in the game and the difficulty ramps up at a steady, reasonable rate. Portal is good at introducing new mechanics, building upon those mechanics and reminding you subtly how they work. And there are some genuinely funny moments, which is all too rare in gaming. What still impresses me that Portal still holds up today, even after the sequel. I can’t think of a reason you shouldn’t play Portal 1 before getting into Portal 2. The ideas and game mechanics started here would go on to create a much better sequel and an entirely new genre. A genre that I think has only begun. For puzzle and FPS players, Portal is a good introduction to the series and genre and worth giving a go.

Very good game!

Ya sé que voy un poco tarde, pero me he pasado el juego después de haberlo comprado a un precio de risa en las rebajas y quiero decir que me ha parecido genial. La mecánica de los portales es simplemente sublime. El diseño de los escenarios, la curva de aprendizaje y la de dificultad son perfectos. Además, el hecho de no saber en ningún momento quién eres y qué estás haciento en realidad y por qué, te mantiene enganchado hasta un final, desde mi punto de vista, muy bueno, que deja una buena sensación después de haber vivido una experiencia intensa.

También quiero decir que el hecho de el juego tenga ya sus añitos me es perfecto, y es que con mi PC (un poco obsoleto para jugar a los juegos más recientes) lo puedo correr a ULTRA (luce genial, por cierto) y a 70-90 FPS,

Es verdad que el modo historia es un poco corto, pero los últimos niveles suponen un verdadero desafío y hay los modos de mapas modificados o con comentarios de los desarrolladores (una idea genial que me gustaría ver en más títulos) pueden añadirle un buen puñado de horas. Por si fuera poco, aún queda Portal2... ¡A darle caña!

This game is awesome. The feeling you have when you figure out a more complicated puzzle is great.

The relationship between the story and the gameplay itself is very well made. [spoiler]First, you're just a test subject going through test chambers, but suddenly you're using the "test this for us" equipment you got to escape from this building and this people (actually just an evil IA).[/spoiler] And it is at that moment the game gets [b]really dark[/b]. When you're completing levels, you get clues of said darkness — [spoiler]"THE CAKE IS A LIE"[/spoiler] — and the game game goes between smart, funny, sadist and horrifying.

As a negative point, the game is pretty short, but there is Portal 2 for us!

Portal is a game that I highly recommend and should be on everyone's library: it takes a high quantity of effort to not like it.

This was a triumph!
I'm making a note here:
Huge success!

It's hard to overstate
my satisfaction.

Aperture Science:
We do what we must
because we can
For the good of all of us.
Except the ones who are dead.

But there's no sense crying
over every mistake.
You just keep on trying
'til you run out of cake.
And the science gets done.
And you make a neat gun
for the people who are
still alive.

I'm not even angry...
I'm being so sincere right now.
Even though you broke my heart,
and killed me.

And tore me to pieces.
And threw every piece into a fire.
As they burned it hurt because
I was so happy for you!

Now, these points of data
make a beautiful line.
And we're out of beta.
We're releasing on time!
So I'm GLaD I got burned!
Think of all the things we learned!
for the people who are
still alive.

Go ahead and leave me...
I think I'd prefer to stay inside...
Maybe you'll find someone else
to help you.
Maybe Black Mesa?
That was a joke. Ha Ha. Fat Chance!

Anyway this cake is great!
It's so delicious and moist!

Look at me: still talking
when there's science to do!
When I look out there,
it makes me glad I'm not you.

I've experiments to run.
There is research to be done.
On the people who are
still alive.
And believe me I am
still alive.
I'm doing science and I'm
still alive.
I feel fantastic and I'm
still alive.
While you're dying I'll be
still alive.
And when you're dead I will be
still alive

Still alive.

Still alive.

[i] My system for game ratings is an "out of ten" system based on five distinct categories, each of which can receive 2 points. Each category can earn up to one extra point, should I find this aspect to well exceed my personal expectations. [/i]

[b] Story / Characters: 2/2 - "Great" [/b]

While this game may seem like nothing more than a first person puzzle shooter on the surface, there is some pretty remarkable indirect storytelling going on. GLaDOS' pitch-black, sarcastic lines serve to develop her as the main antagonist, when she at first seemed like your guide. Those helpful "pre-recorded" messages grow more and more sardonic with each passing chamber, and I grew to fear her very quickly. The insane writings found on the wall drive home the true significance of the events of the game, and we begin to realize that this game is much more than just a puzzler designed to show off the physics capabilities of Havok and the Source engine. Even the symbolic Companion Cube felt like a character, in the oddest of ways. For what this game is, we could hardly ask for better.

[b] Gameplay Mechanics: 3/2 - "Sublime" [/b]

Now we arrive at the game's shining aspect. The mechanic used within the game, involving the ability to traverse through two different portals manually placed throughout the world to traverse obstacles, is profoundly inventive. No other game had ever used the mechanic in this way before, to my knowledge. It is simple and easy to control, yet complex and mindbending in it application. This game requires you to use your brain, and it proves challenging yet not too confusing. The lack of a timer in test chambers mean players have all the time they need to remain in a place and fool around a bit with the portal device. It is one of the most fun experiences I've had in any video game. 

[b] Visual Fidelity: 1.5/2 - "Good" [/b]

Immediately following this game's greatest triumph is its biggest failing, and even here I am nitpicking. The environment is, for the majority of the game, very simple and uninteresting. The same wall texture is plastered on every room with little variance, and these textures can certainly appear rather muddy even on full settings. The environment is not really that interesting, but then again it is not trying to be. This game's few developers clearly wanted to utilize the characteristics of the player's surroundings to challenge the player as opposed to provide him eye candy. The visual aspect is good, but we have certainly seen better, even at the time this game was made.

[b] Soundtrack: 2/2 - "Great" [/b]

The soundtrack of this game, though limited, is very well done. I will never forget the first time I finished Test Chamber 19, and this is not because of the somewhat expected plot twist or because of the tense situation. I will never forget it because of the song which played as you inched slowly toward the flames of the incinerator - "4000 Degrees Kelvin". Its progression and style added to the scene in spades and perfectly set the tone of the moment and, in fact, the game as a whole. Also there is "Still Alive", which is renowned throughout the world of gaming as one of the better songs ever written for a game. Its upbeat yet inherently sad melody serves as the perfect and unforgettable ending to an equally perfect and unforgettable experience.

[b] Personal Enjoyment: 2/2 - "Great" [/b]

For this game, deciding on how to score the personal enjoyment section was very difficult. I have two sets of feelings for this, but I will score this based on the more objective one. While playing this game, I was unable to appreciate its greatness. I wasn't thinking about how great it was while fighting GLaDOS nor was I admiring the almost nonexistent soundtrack while I played through a chamber. I was only considering the game and what I had to do to get through it, and it is the strange level of immersion I felt which sets this game apart from all others. In an objective sense, I can't bring myself to give this game more than a 2/2, but make no mistake; this, paired with Portal 2, is my all-time favorite game. 

[b] Grand Total: 10+/10 [/b]

Thanks to the small b-team of Digipen graduates within Valve for giving us one of the most unforgettable and iconic games ever made. It will, most likely, always and forever be my favorite.
